questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with progressive gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline. CT imaging shows enlarged ventricles, and a lumbar puncture reveals normal CSF pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hydrocephalus

  • Hydrocephalus: Increase in CSF volume, causing ventricular enlargement and symptoms of raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • Obstructive hydrocephalus: Caused by a blockage within the ventricular system (e.g., tumours, lesions).
  • Communicating hydrocephalus: Results from impaired reabsorption of CSF, often due to infections or haemorrhage.
  • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH):
  • Classic triad: Gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline.
  • Imaging: Ventriculomegaly without raised CSF pressure.
  • Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunt (VPS) to drain excess CSF.

Explanation:

Option A) Obstructive Hydrocephalus: Ventricular dilation with elevated CSF pressure, typically due to a blockage. Imaging would show dilated ventricles, but CSF pressure is high, unlike NPH.

Option B) Communicating Hydrocephalus: Impaired CSF reabsorption with elevated CSF pressure, often related to meningitis or trauma.

Option C) Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH): Correct. Enlarged ventricles with normal CSF pressure. Classic triad of symptoms: gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline. Symptoms may improve after CSF drainage.

Option D) Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension: Increased intracranial pressure, typically seen in young overweight females, with normal-sized ventricles.

Key Points:

NPH presents with a triad of symptoms and normal lumbar puncture pressure. Obstructive hydrocephalus often requires urgent surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with acute obstructive hydrocephalus due to a brain tumour. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate treatment?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Hydrocephalus

  • Acute Hydrocephalus: An emergency that can lead to rapid deterioration, requiring immediate intervention.
  • External Ventricular Drain (EVD):
    • Used as a temporary measure in emergencies to relieve pressure by diverting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
    • Inserted through a burr hole, typically at Kocher's point.
  • Ventriculoperitoneal Shunt:
    • Long-term solution for hydrocephalus, involves diverting CSF from the ventricles to the peritoneal cavity.
    • Complications include infection, blockage, and overdrainage.
  • Endoscopic Third Ventriculostomy:
    • Preferred in obstructive hydrocephalus due to aqueductal stenosis, allowing drainage between the third ventricle and subarachnoid cisterns.
    • Risk of reblockage and serious complications like basilar artery damage.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect: Lumbar puncture is not used in acute obstructive hydrocephalus due to the risk of brain herniation.

Option B) Correct: External ventricular drain (EVD) is the emergency treatment of choice for acute obstructive hydrocephalus to relieve pressure and manage the condition.

Option C) Incorrect: Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is used for long-term management, not emergency situations.

Option D) Incorrect: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy is useful in selected cases of obstructive hydrocephalus but not for immediate relief.

Key Points:

EVD for emergency relief of acute hydrocephalus.Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the mainstay for long-term treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with confusion, low-grade fever, and focal neurological deficits. He has a history of chronic sinus infections. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brain Abscess

  • Etiology: Can occur due to direct exposure (fracture, surgery), hematogenous spread (dental, respiratory infection, endocarditis), or no clear primary infection.
  • Imaging: CT scan with contrast shows a ring-enhancing lesion; diffusion-weighted MRI can distinguish abscess from a tumor.
  • Management: Urgent drainage is crucial; untreated abscesses can lead to rupture into the ventricles with high mortality.
  • Prophylaxis: Up to 50% of patients develop seizures, so consider anticonvulsants.

Explanation:

Option A) Glioblastoma: While it may present as a mass lesion, it does not typically present with infection-like symptoms such as fever or systemic infections.

Option B) Brain abscess: Correct. The patient's symptoms and the finding of a ring-enhancing lesion on CT are suggestive of a brain abscess, often associated with sinus infections.

Option C) Meningioma: Typically presents as a slow-growing, non-infectious mass and lacks systemic infectious symptoms.

Option D) Stroke: Would present with sudden neurological symptoms without signs of infection.

Key Points:

Ring-enhancing lesion on CT with infection symptoms suggests a brain abscess.

Early surgical drainage is the main treatment.

choices.text: Coiling of the aneurysm if suitable
Observation and repeat CT in 24 hours

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a sudden-onset, severe headache described as "the worst headache of his life." He briefly lost consciousness and vomited. CT scan shows blood in the subarachnoid space, and angiography reveals an aneurysm at the bifurcation of the internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Subarachnoid Haemorrhage (SAH)

  • Cause: 80% due to ruptured aneurysms, mostly located in the Circle of Willis; 20% due to arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) or idiopathic causes (e.g., perimesencephalic SAH).
  • Risk Factors: Age, female gender, smoking, hypertension, cocaine abuse, polycystic kidney disease, and family history.
  • Clinical Features: Sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache, often described as the worst headache ever, with associated nausea, vomiting, and possible loss of consciousness.
  • Imaging: CT scan within 12 hours confirms bleeding in >98% of cases. Lumbar puncture if CT is negative.
  • Management: Early intervention is critical. Coiling (endovascular embolization) is preferred if feasible, with clipping performed for complex or unsuitable aneurysms.
  • Medications: Nimodipine (to prevent vasospasm), IV fluids, and supportive care are essential.

Explanation:

Option A) Immediate clipping of the aneurysm: Clipping is an option but is more invasive. Coiling is preferred when feasible due to lower morbidity.

Option B) Coiling of the aneurysm if suitable: Correct. Endovascular coiling is less invasive and preferred for treating aneurysms when the anatomy allows.

Option C) Observation and repeat CT in 24 hours: Observation is not appropriate for a ruptured aneurysm due to the risk of rebleeding.

Option D) Administration of high-dose corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are not indicated for the acute management of aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Key Points:

Prophylaxis: Nimodipine is given to prevent vasospasm and improve outcomes.Initial Management: Coiling is preferred over clipping where feasible.

choices.text: Intravenous antihypertensives to lower blood pressure
Hourly neurological observation and blood pressure monitoring

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and reduced consciousness. A CT scan shows a large right frontal lobe haemorrhage. He has a history of hypertension (current blood pressure - 128/80 mmhg) but is not on anticoagulants. What is the initial step in management?
questions.solution:
Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH)

  • Prevalence: Accounts for 10-15% of all strokes.
  • Presentation: Sudden focal deficits, headache, reduced consciousness, and signs of raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • Risk Factors: Hypertension, amyloid angiopathy, anticoagulation, and vascular anomalies (e.g., aneurysm or AVM).
  • Initial Management:
    • Monitoring: Hourly neurological checks and blood pressure monitoring.
    • Blood Pressure: Only lower acutely if MAP >130 mmHg.
    • Reversal of Anticoagulants: For patients on blood thinners (e.g., warfarin).
    • Further Imaging: Required to rule out underlying lesions (e.g., aneurysm, AVM) in atypical bleeds.
    • Surgical Indications: Craniotomy is reserved for younger, fitter patients with large, accessible haemorrhages or those with raised ICP.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Craniotomy is reserved for cases with raised intracranial pressure or younger, fitter patients with more accessible bleeds.

Option B) Incorrect. There is no need for anticoagulation reversal in a patient not on anticoagulants.

Option C) Incorrect. Blood pressure should only be lowered acutely if mean arterial pressure is exceedingly high (>130 mmHg).

Option D) Correct. Initial management of ICH focuses on close monitoring, neuro-observations, and blood pressure control.

Key Points:

ICH accounts for 10-15% of strokes.Clot evacuation can relieve raised ICP but does not reverse neurological deficits caused by the haemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following gene defects is associated with Neurofibromatosis type 1 and astrocytomas?
questions.solution:
Option A) PTEN (chromosome 10): Incorrect. PTEN mutations are associated with Cowden syndrome and various cancers, not Neurofibromatosis type 1.

Option B) Neurofibromin (chromosome 17): Correct. Mutations in the neurofibromin gene on chromosome 17 are associated with Neurofibromatosis type 1 and increased risk of astrocytomas.

Option C) Neurofibromin (chromosome 22): Incorrect. This refers to the gene involved in Neurofibromatosis type 2, not type 1.

Option D) p53 (chromosome 17): Incorrect. Mutations in p53 are linked to Li-Fraumeni syndrome and other cancers, but not directly to Neurofibromatosis type 1.

Chromosomal Abnormalities and Brain Tumours

Key Points:

  • Neurofibromin gene defect in NF1 is linked with astrocytomas and neurofibromas.NF2 affects the schwannomin gene and causes acoustic neuromas.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with a history of gradual hearing loss, balance issues, and occasional tinnitus. MRI reveals a mass at the cerebellopontine angle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the tumor location and presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Options:

Option A) Pituitary adenoma: Typically presents with endocrine disturbances and visual field deficits (e.g., bitemporal hemianopia), not hearing loss or balance issues.

Option B) Vestibular schwannoma: Correct. A mass at the cerebellopontine angle leading to hearing loss, balance disturbance, and tinnitus is characteristic of vestibular schwannoma.

Option C) Olfactory groove meningioma: Presents with anosmia (loss of smell) and Foster Kennedy syndrome (ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilloedema).

Option D) Glioma of the occipital lobe: Often presents with homonymous hemianopia with central sparing, not hearing or balance issues.

Tumour Locations and Expected Deficits

Key Points:

Vestibular Schwannoma: Commonly affects cranial nerve VIII, leading to hearing loss and balance disturbances.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with new-onset seizures and is found to have multiple brain metastases on MRI. Which is the most likely primary site of his metastases?
questions.solution:
Option A) Breast: Can metastasize to the brain, but less common in men compared to lung cancer.

Option B) Renal: Renal cell carcinoma can spread to the brain, but it is less frequent than lung cancer.

Option C) Lung: Correct. Lung cancer is the most common cause of brain metastases.

Option D) Melanoma: Melanoma often metastasizes to the brain, but lung cancer remains the most common primary source.


Key Points:

Lung cancer is the most common primary tumour causing brain metastases.Brain metastases often indicate advanced disease and require multimodal treatment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with new-onset seizures and headaches. A contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals a ring-enhancing lesion. MRI confirms the diagnosis. What is the most likely type of tumour in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A) Meningiomas typically show uniform enhancement on contrast CT and are less likely to present as ring-enhancing lesions.

Option B) Correct. Gliomas are common supratentorial brain tumours and appear as ring-enhancing lesions on contrast CT. They are usually managed surgically, though surgery is life-extending rather than curative.

Option C) Pituitary adenomas arise in the sellar region and do not present with ring-enhancing lesions.

Option D) Schwannomas are peripheral nerve sheath tumours and are not typically found within the brain substance.

Supratentorial Brain Tumours

Key Points:

MRI is superior to CT for evaluating brain tumors. Metastasis is the main differential diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with headaches and visual disturbances. MRI shows a 12 mm mass in the sellar region compressing the optic chiasm. Hormonal tests reveal elevated prolactin levels. What is the best initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Pituitary Tumours

  • Types of Tumours: Most pituitary tumours are benign adenomas, classified into microadenomas (<10 mm) and macroadenomas (>10 mm).
  • Hormone Secretion: 30% of tumours are prolactinomas, 20% non-functioning, 15% secrete growth hormone, 10% secrete ACTH.
  • Symptoms: Visual disturbances in macroadenomas due to optic chiasm compression; galactorrhea or acromegalic features in functioning adenomas.
  • Treatment:
    • Prolactinoma: Dopamine agonists (bromocriptine or cabergoline).
    • GH or ACTH-secreting tumours: Dopamine agonists or somatostatin analogues.
    • Surgery (transsphenoidal resection) is reserved for visual compromise or non-responsive tumours.
  • Complications: CSF leak, diabetes insipidus, pituitary insufficiency, and pituitary apoplexy (sudden haemorrhage or infarction in the tumour requiring urgent management with IV steroids and possibly surgery).

Explanation:

Option A) Transsphenoidal surgery is indicated if there is severe visual loss or if the tumour doesn't respond to medical treatment.

Option B) Correct. Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, is the first-line treatment for prolactinomas.

Option C) Somatostatin analogues like octreotide are used for growth hormone-secreting tumors, not prolactinomas.

Option D) Craniotomy is reserved for large tumours or when the transsphenoidal approach is not possible.

Key Points:

Macroadenomas (>10 mm): Often present with visual field deficits.Medical Management: Prolactinomas respond well to dopamine agonists.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with occipital headaches exacerbated by coughing. Neurological examination reveals signs of cerebellar dysfunction. MRI shows descent of the cerebellar tonsils by 7 mm below the foramen magnum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chiari Malformations and Dandy-Walker Syndrome

  • Chiari I Malformation:
    • Descent of cerebellar tonsils >5 mm through the foramen magnum. Presents with headaches, cerebellar signs, and possible syrinx formation.
    • Treatment: Shunting and foramen magnum decompression.
  • Chiari II Malformation:
    • Involves descent of cerebellar tonsils and vermis, often associated with myelomeningocele and hydrocephalus, presenting in infancy.
  • Dandy-Walker Malformation:
    • Presents with macrocephaly, developmental delay, and hydrocephalus. Imaging shows a large posterior fossa cyst and hypoplastic cerebellar vermis.
    • Treatment: Shunting.

Explanation:

Option A) Dandy-Walker malformation typically presents in infancy with macrocephaly and developmental delay. Imaging shows a large posterior fossa cyst and hypoplastic cerebellar vermis, which is not the case here.

Option B) Correct. Chiari I malformation involves >5 mm descent of cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum and typically presents in young adults with symptoms like headaches exacerbated by coughing and cerebellar dysfunction.

Option C) Chiari II malformation involves more extensive descent (tonsils and vermis) and is associated with myelomeningocele and hydrocephalus, which presents in infancy.

Option D) Arnold-Chiari malformation is an older term, sometimes used interchangeably with Chiari II but not relevant here.

Key Points:

  • Chiari I: >5 mm tonsillar descent.
  • Chiari II: Tonsillar and vermis descent, associated with myelomeningocele.
  • Dandy-Walker: Posterior fossa cyst, hypoplastic vermis, hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with an abnormally shaped head and delayed developmental milestones. Examination reveals a narrow, boat-shaped head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Craniosynostosis

  • Craniosynostosis: Premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, leading to characteristic skull deformities and potential for increased intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • Management: Surgical correction to prevent raised ICP and correct skull deformities.

Explanation:

Option A) Brachycephaly results from premature fusion of the coronal sutures, leading to a broad, shortened head shape.

Option B) Correct. Scaphocephaly is due to premature fusion of the sagittal suture, leading to a narrow, boat-shaped head.

Option C) Plagiocephaly results from unilateral fusion of the coronal or lambdoid sutures, causing asymmetry of the skull.

Option D) Trigonocephaly is due to premature fusion of the metopic suture, resulting in a pointed, narrow forehead.

Key Points:

Scaphocephaly: Sagittal suture fusion, narrow boat-shaped head.

Brachycephaly: Coronal suture fusion, broad head.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe, paroxysmal, lancinating pain in the distribution of the right maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. The pain is triggered by eating and brushing his teeth. Medications such as carbamazepine have failed to control the symptoms. MRI reveals neurovascular compression. Which is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Trigeminal Neuralgia Management

  • Trigeminal Neuralgia: Paroxysmal, lancinating pain typically without neurological disturbance; often triggered by stimuli like eating or brushing teeth.
  • Etiology: Often due to neurovascular compression (most commonly by the superior cerebellar artery) or demyelination (e.g., multiple sclerosis).
  • First-line treatment: Carbamazepine or other anticonvulsants.
  • Surgical options: When medications fail, microvascular decompression is the first-line surgical option for cases with neurovascular compression.
  • Other treatments: Rhizotomy or radiosurgery for patients not suitable for surgery.

Explanation:

Option A) Microvascular decompression: The preferred treatment for trigeminal neuralgia when neurovascular compression is identified and medications fail.

Option B) Percutaneous Gasserian rhizolysis: Minimally invasive option but typically for patients who are poor surgical candidates.

Option C) Stereotactic radiosurgery: Non-invasive but reserved for patients where surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful

Option D) Cordotomy: Not typically used for trigeminal neuralgia; more appropriate for pain control in cases of terminal cancer.

Key Points:

  • Trigeminal neuralgia is characterised by severe, unilateral, lancinating pain.Microvascular decompression is the gold standard for surgical treatment when neurovascular compression is present.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a complaint of severe headaches, nausea, and blurred vision. On examination, the child has difficulty with upgaze and bulging fontanelles. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Raised Intracranial Pressure (ICP)

  • Symptoms of Raised ICP:
    • Headache: Worsens with coughing, bending forward.
    • Nausea/Vomiting: Common in raised ICP.
    • Papilloedema: Takes time to develop, indicating chronic raised ICP.
    • Vision Issues: Blurred vision, double vision, pupil abnormalities.
    • Parinaud's Syndrome (Sunsetting): Loss of upgaze, indicating dorsal midbrain compression.
  • Infant Presentation:
  • Bulging Fontanelles, prominent scalp veins, increased head circumference.
  • Emergency Management:
    • Raise the head of the bed.
    • Administer mannitol or hypertonic saline.
    • Arrange urgent CT imaging to rule out cerebral herniation.

Explanation:

Option A) Incorrect. Low ICP is associated with headaches that worsen when standing, not lying down or bending forward.

Option B) Correct. The symptoms of high-pressure headaches, sunsetting sign, bulging fontanelles, and papilloedema suggest raised ICP, likely due to hydrocephalus in this case.

Option C) Incorrect. Tension headaches do not typically cause the symptoms of papilloedema, sunsetting sign, or severe nausea related to intracranial pressure.

Option D) Incorrect. Migraine with aura can cause headaches, but it does not typically present with papilloedema or signs of increased ICP like the sunsetting sign.

Key Points:

Raised ICP causes vision loss and can progress to herniation.The sunsetting sign indicates dorsal midbrain compression.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a sudden, severe headache, vomiting, and confusion. On examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 11, and he has mild right-sided weakness. According to the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies (WFNS) grading, what is his grade of subarachnoid haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Option A) Grade I: Incorrect. Grade I indicates a GCS of 15 with no focal neurological deficits.

Option B) Grade II: Incorrect. Grade II corresponds to a GCS of 13-14 without focal neurological deficits.

Option C) Grade III: Incorrect. Grade III corresponds to a GCS of 13-14 with focal neurological deficits.

Option D) Grade IV: Correct. Grade IV is defined as a GCS of 7-12 with or without focal neurological deficits. The patient's GCS is 11, and he has a focal neurological deficit (right-sided weakness), fitting this grade.

WFNS Grading of Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

  • The WFNS grading system is based on the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) and the presence of focal neurological deficits. It helps stratify the severity of subarachnoid haemorrhage and guide treatment decisions.

Key Points:

  • Grade III and IV: Include patients with moderate impairment and focal deficits.
